case_name: R. P. Kapur & Ors. v. State of Punjab & Ors.

facts.text: This is a writ petition under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights under Arts. 14 and 21.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by K. DAS J.-This is a writ petition. The three petitioners before us are  1  R. P. Kapur, a member of was serving as a Commissioner in the State of Punjab,  2  Sheila Kapur, his wife, and  3  Kaushalya Devi, his mother-in-law. They have moved this Court under Art. 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of their rights under Arts. 14 and 21 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Petitioners are R. P. Kapur, Commissioner in Punjab; Sheila Kapur, his wife; Kaushalya Devi, his mother-in-law.

anchor.surface_text: The three petitioners before us are  1  R. P. Kapur, a member of was serving as a Commissioner in the State of Punjab,  2  Sheila Kapur, his wife, and  3  Kaushalya Devi, his mother-in-law.

facts.text: Respondents include State of Punjab, Sardar Pratap Singh Kairon (Chief Minister), and certain police, administrative, magisterial officials involved in investigation of criminal cases against petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: which rights they say have been violated by the respondents who are the State of Punjab, Sardar Pratap Singh Kairon, Chief Minister thereof, and certain officials, police, administrative and magisterial who have been companyducting, or are companynected with, the investigation or inquiry into a number of criminal cases.

facts.text: Petitioner 1 (R.P. Kapur) incurred wrath of Chief Minister for not giving evidence in Grewal case (Karnal Murder Case) involving D.S. Grewal, SP Karnal.

anchor.surface_text: Briefly stated the case of the petitioners is that petitioner number 1 had the misfortune to incur the wrath of the Chief Minister of the State. It is alleged that the Chief Minister was annoyed with petitioner number 1, because the latter did number show his readiness to give evidence for the prosecution in a case known as the Karnal Murder Case  later referred to as the Grewal case  in which one D. S. Grewal, then Superintendent of Police, Karnal,

facts.text: Grewal case transferred by Supreme Court to Special Judge at Delhi, trial commenced May/June 1959.

anchor.surface_text: That case was transferred by this Court to a Special Judge, at Delhi, who companymenced the trial sometime in May June 1959. Petitioner number 1 was at the time Com- missioner of Ambala, and he alleges that he was told by the Chief Minister that it was proposed to cite the Deputy Commissioner and the Deputy Inspector-General of Police as prosecution witnesses in the said case

facts.text: Petitioner 1 passed orders as Commissioner Patiala Division in Sangrur case adverse to Surinder Kairon (son of Chief Minister), involving properties worth Rs. 9 lacs.

anchor.surface_text: Another reason for the displeasure of the Chief Minister, as alleged in the petition, related to certain orders which petitioner number 1 had passed as Commissioner, Patiala Division, in a revenue case known as the Sangrur case. We shall presently give more details of that case, but it is enough to state here that the allegation is that in that case petitioner number 1 passed certain orders, involving the disposal of properties worth about Rs. 9 lacs, which were adverse to one Surinder Kairon, son of the Chief Minister.

facts.text: Special procedure adopted in investigation of criminal cases against petitioners using C.I.D. Police to harass them.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated that as a result of the displeasure which petitioner number 1 bad incurred for the two reasons mentioned above, a special procedure was adopted in the investigation of the criminal cases instituted against the petitioners and some new cases were started through the instrumentality of the C. 1. D. Police with a view to subject the petitioners to harassment and persecution.

facts.text: Four illustrative criminal cases: Sethi's case (FIR 304/1958), Dhingra's case (FIR 39/1959), Orphanage case (FIR 135/1959), Ayurvedic Fund case (FIR 26/1960).

anchor.surface_text: The four cases mentioned in the original petition are - F.I.R. number 304 of 1958, given by one M. L. Sethi, referred to hereinafter for brevity as Sethis case F.I.R. number 39 of 1959, instituted on the companyplaint of one M. L. Dhingra, called hereinafter as Dhingras case F.I.R. number 135 of 1959, instituted on the companyplaint of the Civil Supply Officer, Karnal, the accused in this case being the State Orphanage Advisory Board of which petitioner number I was Vice-President at the relevant time and Kartar Singh, farm manager of Kaushalya Devi, called the Orphanage case and F.I.R. number 26 of 1960, instituted on the companyplaint of Daryao Sing, D.S.P., C.I.D., Karnal,

facts.text: Petitioners previously moved Punjab High Court to quash proceedings in Sethi's and Dhingra's cases without success; appeal to Supreme Court in Sethi's case unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated on behalf of the respondents that in the two cases called Setbis case and Dhingras case, the petitioners had moved the High Court without success for quashing the proceedings and in Sethis case, an appeal to this Court against the order of the High Court also proved unsuccessful.

facts.text: Petition for contempt against Chief Minister dismissed in limine by Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is also pointed out that a petition made by petitioner number 1 in the High Court for proceeding by way of companytempt of companyrt against the Chief Minister on some of the allegations number raised or allegations similar in nature, was dismissed in limine

facts.text: Court finds petitioners have not established displeasure of Chief Minister due to Grewal and Sangrur cases.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, companye to the companyclusion that the petitioners have number established what they have alleged, namely, that R. P. Kapur, one of the petitioners, had incurred the displeasure of the Chief Minister by reason of what happened in the Grewal case and the Sangrur case.

facts.text: Sethi's case: Complaint dated December 10, 1958 by M.L. Sethi, sent to Additional Inspector General of Police on December 23, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Sethis case started on a companyplaint which it was said was sent direct to the Chief Minister. Four material allegations about fraudulent misrepresentation were made in that companyplaint. ... Though the companyplaint was dated December 10, 1958, it appears to have been made over to the Additional Inspector General of Police on December 23, 1958.

facts.text: In Sethi's case, Additional IGP ordered Sardar Hardayal Singh, DSP C.I.D. Amritsar, to register case and investigate personally.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Inspector General of Police then appears to have passed an order to the following effect Register a case and investigate personally . This was addressed to Sardar Hardayal Singh, S. P. Thereupon Sardar Hardayal Singh, Deputy Superintendent of Police, C.I.D., Amritsar, appears to have drawn up a first information report.

facts.text: Court holds procedure in Sethi's case legal under s.551 CrPC as officers superior in rank.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Inspector General of Police, C.I.D. had power to deal with Sethis companyplaint and had further power to direct investigation of the same by Sardar Hardayal Singh who as a police officer superior in rank to an officer incharge of a police station companyld exercise powers of an officer in charge of a police station in respect of the same.

facts.text: Dhingra's case: Complaint dated February 27, 1959 sent to Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: Turning number to Dhingras case, the position is this. Admittedly a companyplaint dated February 27, 1959, was sent to the Chief Minister with a companyering letter

facts.text: Chief Minister endorsed on Dhingra's complaint: Inspector General Police sick, Addl IGP take immediate action, prima facie report.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister wrote on this Inspector General, Police, is sick. Will Add1. Inspector General please take immediate action in taking over papers from Government departments companycerned and the papers with Sri Dhingra. Please give a prima facie report.

facts.text: Court holds procedure in Dhingra's case legal under s.551 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position as to the institution of Dhingras case and its investigation is the same as in Sethis case. The legal sanction for both is s. 551, Code of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: Orphanage case (FIR 135/1959) on complaint of Civil Supply Officer Karnal against State Orphanage Advisory Board (petitioner 1 Vice-President) and Kartar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: We go number to the remaining two cases, the Orphanage Case and the Ayurvedic Fund, case. One was instituted on the companyplaint of the Civil Supply Officer, Karnal, ... the accused in this case being the State Orphanage Advisory Board of which R. P. Kapur was the Vice President at the relevant time, and Kartar Sing, farm manager of Kaushalya Devi.

facts.text: Ayurvedic Fund case (FIR 26/1960) on complaint of Daryao Singh DSP CID Karnal against petitioner 1 and others.

anchor.surface_text: the other on the statement of Daryao Sing, Deputy Superintendent of Police, C. 1. D., Karnal. The Ayurvedic Fund case is against R. P. Kapur and certain other persons,

facts.text: Court concludes no special procedure unknown to law or unequal treatment; writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we have companye to the companyclusion that the petitioners are number entitled to succeed and the writ petition must be dismissed,

facts.text: Chief Minister did not file affidavit despite serious allegations against him.

anchor.surface_text: Serious allegations have been made against the Chief Minister in this case. He is a party respondent and had numberice of the allegations made. ... In view of the allegations made against him, we companysider that the Chief Minister owed a duty to this Court to file an affidavit

facts.text: Sangrur case: Court of Wards decided on June 19, 1958 to release estate after partitioning between two widows.

anchor.surface_text: What happened in that case was this. The late Sardar Mukan Sing of Sangrur left two widows, Sardarni Pritam Kuar and Sardarni Pavitar Kaur ... On June 19, 1958, the Court of Wards decided to release the estate after partitioning the immovable property between the two widows.

facts.text: Petitioner 1 wrote to Chief Secretary on May 28, 1959 about Sethi and Dhingra cases, no allegation against CM then.

anchor.surface_text: On May 28, 1959, petitioner number 1 wrote to the Chief Secretary about Sethis case and Dhingras case, but numberallegation was made therein against the Chief Minister.

facts.text: Petitioner 1 filed petitions in Punjab High Court on June 29, 1959 to quash Sethi and Dhingra proceedings.

issues.text: whether in the matter of institution and investigation of these cases a special procedure unknown to law has been adopted

anchor.surface_text: Two questions have been posed before us in relation to these cases one is if in the matter of institution and investigation of these cases a special procedure unknown to law has been adopted and the other is if the petitioners have been singled out for unequal

issues.text: if the petitioners have been singled out for unequal treatment in administering the law relating to the institution and investigation of criminal cases in the State

anchor.surface_text: and the other is if the petitioners have been singled out for unequal treatment in administering the law relating to the institution and investigation of criminal cases in the State. The two questions are in one sense connected, for if a special procedure unknown to law has been adopted against the petitioners, that by itself will be a denial of the right of the equal protection of the laws.

issues.text: does this amount to adopting a procedure unknown to law or even to unequal treatment so as to attract Art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The short question before us is-does this amount to adopting a procedure unknown to law or even to unequal treatment so as to attract Art. 14 of the Constitution ? Learned Counsel for the petitioners has taken us through the relevant provisions in Part V, Chapter XIV, of the Code of Criminal Procedure

issues.text: whether in making over the investigation to Sardar Hardayal Singh a special procedure unknown to law was adopted or the law as to the investigation of cases was administered with an evil eye or unequal hand

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is not whether the reason for which the investigation was made over to Sardar Hardayal Singh is correct or not. The question before us is, whether in making over the investigation to Sardar Hardayal Singh a special procedure unknown to law was adopted or the law as to the investigation of cases was administered with an evil eye or unequal hand.

issues.text: whether the rights of the petitioners guaranteed under Arts. 14 and 21 have been violated

anchor.surface_text: Arts. 14 and 21 of the Constitution, which rights they say have been violated by the respondents who are the State of Punjab, Sardar Pratap Singh Kairon, Chief Minister thereof, and certain officials, police, administrative and magisterial who have been conducting, or are connected with, the investigation or inquiry into a number of criminal cases.

anchor.surface_text: The substantial allegation... is that a special procedure or rather a technique has been devised for circumventing the mandatory provisions of the law... I. D. police 3 registration of first informations after such complaints 4 investigations in advance of the complaints 5 investigation by specially chosen hand-picked... I.D. officials...

arguments.claim: In Sethi's case, procedure legal: Additional IGP (superior officer) directed DSP CID (also superior) under s.551 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Inspector General of Police, C.I.D. had power to deal with Sethis complaint and had further power to direct investigation of the same by Sardar Hardayal Singh who as a police officer superior in rank to an officer incharge of a police station could exercise powers of an officer in charge of a police station in respect of the same.

arguments.claim: s.154 CrPC does not mandate information only to officer in charge of police station; merely procedural for oral info.

anchor.surface_text: First of all, s. 154, Code of Criminal Procedure, does not say that an information of a cognizable offence can only be made to an officer in charge of a police station. That section merely lays down, inter alia, that every information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence, if given orally to an officer in charge of a police station...

arguments.claim: CID officers have statewide jurisdiction per Punjab Police Rules 21.28, 21.32, 25.14 and memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate-General... has drawn our attention to Police Rule 21.28 in the Punjab Police Rules... That rule lays down that the Criminal Investigation Department has no separate jurisdiction and the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Criminal Investigation Department, may decide to take over the control of any particular investigation...

arguments.claim: Even if reason for CID assignment weak, procedure not illegal if within power; open due to petitioners' status.

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is not whether the reason for which the investigation was made over... is correct or not... If the police officer concerned thought that the case should be investigated by the C. I. D. even though for a reason which does not appeal to us-it cannot be said that the procedure adopted was illegal.

arguments.claim: Dhingra's case procedure same as Sethi, legal under s.551 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position as to the institution of Dhingras case and its investigation is the same as in Sethis case. The legal sanction for both is s. 551, Code of Criminal Procedure,

arguments.claim: Orphanage and Ayurvedic cases institution not illegal; CID investigation legal under s.551.

The officers can exercise their powers of investigation under s. 551, Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.text: The petitioners have not established that R. P. Kapur had incurred the displeasure of the Chief Minister by reason of what happened in the Grewal case and the Sangrur case.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, come to the conclusion that the petitioners have not established what they have alleged, namely, that R. P. Kapur, one of the petitioners, had incurred the displeasure of the Chief Minister by reason of what happened in the Grewal case and the Sangrur case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timeline inconsistencies and lack of early allegations show no causal link between alleged events and criminal cases.

holdings.text: The procedure adopted in Sethi's case is legal under s.551 CrPC as superior police officers could exercise powers of station officer.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Inspector General of Police, C.I.D. had power to deal with Sethis complaint and had further power to direct investigation of the same by Sardar Hardayal Singh who as a police officer superior in rank to an officer incharge of a police station could exercise powers of an officer in charge of a police station in respect of the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.551 empowers superior officers statewide; Additional IGP and DSP CID qualified.

holdings.text: s.154 CrPC does not mandate that information of cognizable offence can only be given to officer in charge of police station.

anchor.surface_text: First of all, s. 154, Code of Criminal Procedure, does not say that an information of a cognizable offence can only be made to an officer in charge of a police station. That section merely lays down, inter alia, that every information relating to the commission

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section is procedural for oral information to station officer, not exclusive.

holdings.text: CID officers have statewide jurisdiction under Punjab Police Rules 21.28 etc., allowing takeover of investigations.

anchor.surface_text: Police Rule 21.28 in the Punjab Police Rules, 1934, Vol. III,... That rule lays down that the Criminal Investigation Department has no separate jurisdiction and the Deputy Inspector General of Police, Criminal Investigation Department, may decide to take over the control of any particular investigation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules and memorandum confirm no limited jurisdiction for CID gazetted officers.

holdings.text: Validity of reason for assigning investigation to specific officer irrelevant if officer empowered under law.

anchor.surface_text: The question before us is not whether the reason for which the investigation was made over to Sardar Hardayal Singh is correct or not. The question before us is, whether in making over the investigation to Sardar Hardayal Singh a special procedure unknown to law was adopted or the law as to the investigation of cases was administered with an evil eye or unequal hand.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legality depends on authority, not motive for choice; open for high-status accused.

holdings.text: Procedure in Dhingra's case identical to Sethi's and legal under s.551 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position as to the institution of Dhingras case and its investigation is the same as in Sethis case. The legal sanction for both is s. 551, Code of Criminal Procedure,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same superior officers and powers apply as in Sethi.

holdings.text: No illegality in institution or investigation of Orphanage and Ayurvedic Fund cases; CID empowered under s.551 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: No specific illegality has been brought to our notice with regard to the institution of the Orphanage case... holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard complaints; no shown violations; superior officers authorized.

holdings.text: No special procedure unknown to law or unequal treatment; no violation of Arts.14 and 21; writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we have come to the conclusion that the petitioners are not entitled to succeed and the writ petition must be dismissed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: All cases follow legal procedures under CrPC; no malice or discrimination proven.

holdings.text: Chief Minister owed a duty to file an affidavit given serious allegations against him.

anchor.surface_text: Serious allegations have been made against the Chief Minister in this case. He is a party respondent and had notice of the allegations made. ... In view of the allegations made against him, we consider that the Chief Minister owed a duty to this Court to file an affidavit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Party to serious claims must clarify from personal knowledge; not delegable to subordinates.

precedents.citation: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi  1

anchor.surface_text: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi  1 . The observations occur at page 1160 of the report and are to the effect that it is of companysiderable importance to an accused person that the evidence companylected against him during investigation is companylected under the responsibility of an authorised and companypetent investigating officer.

precedents.case_name: H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: it is of considerable importance to an accused person that the evidence collected against him during investigation is collected under the responsibility of an authorised and competent investigating officer
precedents.cited_holding: provisions of ss. 154 and proviso to s. 3 of Prevention of Corruption Act 1947 and s. 5A of 1952 Amendment are mandatory and violation affects investigation

anchor.surface_text: King Emperor v. Nilkantha  1 . On a certificate by the Advocate-General, the case was companysidered by a Full Bench of the Madras High Court and one of the questions for decision was- Is an Inspector of the Criminal Investigation Department an authority legally companypetent to investigate the facts within the meaning of s. 157, Evidence Act ?

precedents.cited_proposition: whether an Inspector of the Criminal Investigation Department is legally competent to investigate under s. 157 CrPC
precedents.cited_holding: answered in the affirmative by majority

precedents.citation: Pulin Bihari Ghosh v. The King 1

anchor.surface_text: Pulin Bihari Ghosh v. The King 1  on which also some reliance has been placed does number appear to us to be in point that was a case s. 202 and s. 156 3 , Code of Criminal Procedure, and it was held that proceedings under s. 202 and investigation under rb. 156 3  companyld number proceed simultaneously it was further held that a direction under s. 156 3  companyld only be made to an officer in charge of a police station.

precedents.case_name: Pulin Bihari Ghosh v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: proceedings under s. 202 CrPC and investigation under s. 156(3) cannot proceed simultaneously; direction under s. 156(3) only to officer in charge of police station

precedents.citation: Textile Traders Syndicate Ltd. v. State of U. P.  3

anchor.surface_text: Textile Traders Syndicate Ltd. v. State of U. P.  3  where it was held that an Inspector of Police in the Criminal Investigation Department was superior in rank to that of an officer in charge of a police station and under s. 551, Code of Criminal Procedure, he companyld exercise the powers of an officer in charge of a police station throughout the State.

precedents.case_name: Textile Traders Syndicate Ltd. v. State of U. P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Inspector of Police in CID superior in rank to officer in charge of police station and can exercise powers under s. 551 CrPC throughout the State
precedents.cited_holding: Inspector CID could exercise powers of SHO throughout State under s.551 CrPC
